name: GuinnessFan
review_text: This is the latest Keurig coffee maker. I bought it to replace my eight year old Keurig original model (the one with only two sizes and pretty much nothing else.) That machine held on just long enough to keep me from having to buy one of the over-engineered digital monstrosities that Keurig put out between this one and my first machine. There's plenty to like about this machine. First off, the aforementioned lack of digital gimmickry, and the wonderful accompanying blessing of no more nonsense about the K-cup not being on Keurig's list of approved kick-back brands of K-cups. Second, it DOES retain the great idea from the digital machines of a strong brew setting (which I absolutely love.) Third, it has four sizes which is maybe not earth-shaking, but is still kind of nice. One other tiny improvement over my original model is that the compartment stays all the way open instead of springing back down a little like the handle did on my old machine, which is obviously a pretty minor consideration, but one I appreciate to a disproportionate degree.
review_title: Keurig Sees the Writing on the Wall, Takes a Breath, Calms Its Inner Greed Monster, and Nails It
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: madlink
review_text: There appears to be a design or manufacturing flaw in this coffee maker.  Amazon Customer Service have been really good about replacing units, but I am now getting a 3rd unit shipped to me (at no additional cost, I might add).  The first 2 units have the same problem:  Water flows into the cup before any cup-size button has been pressed, and the water is cold.  Maybe the 3rd unit will be okay, but I'm not confident that it will be.  ***Update:  The 3rd unit malfunctions just like the other two.  Unless the manufacturer can convince you that they have fixed the problem, stay away from this model.***
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: D. Coral
review_text: Prior to this new Keurig, my favorite K-Cup machine was the Cuisinart SS-700.  Recently Cuisinart replaced the SS-700 with the poorly engineered flimsy SS-10 model, which I returned because it tends to spray coffee all over the place.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: sazhazman
review_text: I was very happy with this unit for the first 3 weeks. Then I woke up one morning, walked past the machine as I pushed the power button, and within 5 seconds I heard water splashing all over my countertop.  The pump started running without heating, closing the lid, or even pushing a button. I had to hit the power button several times to get it to stop.
review_title: Worked great for about 3 weeks and then...
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

review_text: Junk. I bought this to replace seven year old model that finally died. Purposely got a "no screen" model--read  reviews about the unreliability of models with lcd screens (one we had at work died within 6 months).
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

review_text: Used this unit about 12 times.  Now it starts pumping water as soon as it's turned on and won't stop until the reservoir's empty.  The reset/cleaning and 'burping' fixes don't do a thing.  Unit was delivered 01/18/2018, today is 04/11/2018.  Absolute piece of crap.  Don't buy it.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Kindle Customer
review_text: As I walked into the kitchen the green led went out signaling I needed to begin another water heating cycle.  I pressed the "on" button and hot water began pouring out of the spout splashing and burning my hands.  I put an empty 16 Oz cup under the spout and put my hands under my cold water faucet to stop the burn.  I pulled the plug on the faulty Keurig machine and that stopped the water pouring out.  I was unlucky.  Most of the time I expect i'd get a cold water flow.  But I wonder how many parents let their children make hot chocolate with this bad Keurig.  Depending on their height, quickness and bad luck they could get very hot water in the face.  The machine is not safe.  I tried to contact Keurig.  They refused to help me or even talk to me.  They refuse to acknowledge that this model has a problem.  Instead they spammed me, telling me over and over what great products they have.  Note that others have reported the exact same problem with evidently no response from Keurig.  If you have this machine I urge you to supervise use by children.  BTW, could the reservoir run dry if the machine was not unplugged?  What might happen then?
review_title: Possible Scalding Danger Especially For Children
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

review_text: Planned to give four stars here, but Keurig doesn't include a water filter pod for the included water filter, which is kind of like selling a floor mop with no sponge at the bottom. If they can provide a box of assorted K-cups for free, they can throw in a freakin' starter filter pod. There's my gripe, now here's the better news.

name: bobbobwhite
review_text: This is our 4th Keurig. Expect about 4-5 years life, and descale every 100 cups or so. I remove the unnecessary filter as those tend to cause operational problems later and aren't needed as the water we use is filtered. Machine works much better w/o them. They are a waste of money IMO if you use filtered water..
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Jesse Baynard
review_text: I've tried to resist it, but I have to coincide, Keurig has won the coffee format wars. And while it still won't make espresso like my home Verisimo machine or like the Nespresso machine at work, there's something to be said about it's simplicity and it being the market leader. I can shop a huge variety of beans, blends, flavors and more from nearly any store... in fact some stores have a bigger K cup selection than bagged coffee. I also no longer have to plan ahead to get pods delivered and I can shop local sales to get the pods even cheaper. And the quality of the brew? Pretty good. I find the overall flavor a little weaker than compared to the same Starbucks blend in the Verisimo machine, but if I choose a smaller cup size or hit the strong button there's not enough of a difference to complain about, especially since the pods are cheaper for the Keurig.
review_title: Solid no-nonsense workhorse of a K-Cup machine
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Angel
review_text: I love this keurig k-select! It s a nice smaller, simple size and sleek looking. It works like a dream. I had a hard time finding a keurig that would brew off brand kcups and this one did the job. Had all the features I needed. I also love that you can use the refillable cartridge(sold separately) to use coffee grounds if needed. Water heats up quick, the tank is a little small but not that big of deal refilling and it keeps the machine small. Would definitely recommend. Doesn t have all the bells and whistles but it makes a nice cup of coffee.
review_title: A plus!! Love the Keurig K-select!!!

product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

review_text: I live alone, and I decided to get a Keurig for convenience.  I ordered, and the Keurig arrived promptly and in good shape.  It was easy to operate, instructions were clear.  I appreciated getting a small assortment of K cups, also.  The coffees themselves taste excellent.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Kelly Gravett
review_text: I had my first Keurig for over 6 years before it recently bit the dust. I researched a new single server and read many reviews. I was reluctant to get this particular single-server based on the few reviews that mentioned problems with basic functions, however, every single server I researched had complaints about random malfunctions. When I received my new keurig I could tell as soon as I took it out of the box that it was made more cheaply than the original models. I have used it for my basic morning travel mug of coffee for 3 days now and I am about ready to throw it out the window. Today I had to restart it 10 times, no joke, (as it would start to heat the water and then  randomly shut off after 3 or 5 seconds) before it made one cup of coffee. Thankfully I was in the kitchen to quickly restart it each time, but this will never fly on a normal work week when I'm running around getting myself and 3 children ready for work/school day. It makes a decent cup of coffee once it FINALLY produces one, but who has time for this. I expect more from a $100+ coffee maker. What is Amazon or Keurig doing to make this right for their customers?
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Laurie Jo
review_text: Pay more money for a better Keurig, or better yet.....buy Cuisinart.  They make a better product.  This machine is useless.
review_title: Pay more money for a better Keurig, or better yet
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

review_text: The performance of this product doesn't live up to its looks, or to the performance of older Keurig models either. It feels lightweight and flimsy compared to my previous unit, which would be okay if it worked as well... except it doesn't. The unit turns itself off at random, heats water slowly, and makes coffee at a snail's pace. I used to be able to brew a cup while feeding the dogs and it would be ready when I was done. Now I have to hang around waiting... and that's assuming that the machine didn't decide to turn itself off in the middle of the night so that I have to wait for it to heat up first. (Yes, I followed the instructions to turn off the "Auto Off" feature.) Overall a bad purchase. I'm going to return it and see if there is another model that still has the original build quality and performance.

I purchased the re-useable K-cups (no need to destroy the environment for my caffeine fix) right here on Amazon. And I purchase any coffee I want and save money. Highly recommend.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Margaret
review_text: I liked the cup size selections.  This coffee maker only works when it wants to. We often have to try multiple times to get it to make a cup of coffee.
review_title: I liked the cup size selections
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Julia
review_text: As far as functioning, it does function as designed.  However, if you want a STRONG cup of coffee that you can actually taste, the only way to approximate that is to press the button for extra strong, and then the button for the smallest cup, so you don't get the water going through to the last watery bit, and I was having to do two keurig cups this way to fill one decent mug.  Once you go through that to get a single cup to start your morning, you've baby sat this machine for the same amount of minutes it would have taken to simply make a pot of coffee with a regular drip coffee maker, but with a drip coffee maker you aren't babysitting it, you can walk away and come back and have a strong pot ready to pour into your cup.  I'm selling my Keurig on craigslist after a month of giving it its best shot - it's too big and cumbersome to package up and return.  Now I've got a simple but nice little drip maker and I can get a proper strong cup of coffee - the strongest Kuerig can manage by above method was still very unsatisfying to someone who prefers true strong coffee.  Keurig is really only good if you enjoy moderate regular coffee, one cup here and there, at random times. Certainly not two at once like I was doing, nor stronger brews. I am sure that the people who prefer genuinely strong coffee like I do are only a fraction of the market, and I'm not passing any moral judgments on those who like a more moderate cup, nor am I defending my preference for stronger, but I will say that I'm not simply trying to make a Keurig produce espresso - I just want strong coffee.  If a drip maker can do it, it's not too much to ask.
review_title: Brew is too weak, size is too big, requires too much effort to get one big strong-ish cup of coffee.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Lilly
review_text: The color is beautiful. Just as shown on pic. The water-reservoir tank is cheap plastic and with the lid it's a very flimsy combo. Always afraid I break it bumping into it with my Brita -filter-pitcher. It heats up the water pretty quick and gets your coffee very quick out. I can't say how nice it works with k-cups, cause we use our own coffee - but it's pretty messy with those reusable k-cups. I open the top part, place my reusable k-cups in it, it fills my mug pretty quick with my delicious coffee  but as soon as I open the top again, coffee left overs pour out on countertop in front of the machine. Guess it's really only made for the original k-cups.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Justin
review_text: Pretty simple machine, bought it for moms for mother s day and she loves it. It s straight forward with pictures on the buttons to show what they do. Warms up fast and makes a solid cup of coffee. Only issue I have with these machines is that it always only fills the coffee cup up half way. No matter what size cup I use....... now we gotta press the button twice and the coffee gets a bit of a watered down taste which isn t so great.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: JC
review_text: I had plodded along with a single serve Keurig for years and finally decided to buy one that would make more cups of coffee without doing a whole
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: AZC
review_text: 3/1/18 update: Now that I've used this for a few weeks, I wish the water cover was connected to the unit like all our others. It is an odd shape in the first place and it has flown out of mine and my daughter's hands because of the awewardness and it's not connected to the base. I'm thinking of putting a piece of clear shipping tape on it to save us from chasing it. lol It's in my home office where most people don't go, so I'll likely do that over the weekend.its annoying and when you set it on top of the machine that's not flat, it slides off. Not a good design overall for such a name brand, although the coffee is delicious, hot and it's fast.
review_title: Works, hot drinks, water reservoir lid detached
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Tom L.
review_text: My wife and I finally caved to convenience and bought this Keurig for ourselves. It works very well.  The best part is the freshness and perfect serving temperature of the coffee (or tea) on demand.  The only downside may be the slight guilt associated with the resulting waste stream of K-cups. We are trying a variety of K-cup brands to see what best suits our tastes. Don't be surprised by the fact that some brands are pretty forgettable.  Just try some others.  We picked this model because it had a button to choose a stronger flavor setting. That seems to work pretty well, just by slowing the flow of hot water into the K-cup to provide a bit longer "dwell" on the grounds.  Glad we selected that feature. We have also used some generic "solo pods" available on Amazon that work well for both coffee and tea.
review_title: Functions reliably and can make decent coffee.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: J. Sands
review_text: I live alone so I've always used the Keurig MINI, and loved it. But when I'm entertaining, it was frustrating to have to keep filling the tank between each brew. So I bought the K-Select, thinking it would solve that problem...which it did.  But I assumed that once my company left and I was back to being alone again, I'd be able to completely empty the tank and just add 8-10 oz of water when I want a cup off coffee. Not so. You can only empty the clear plastic tank (on the left side of the machine). But there's still water inside the right tank, and you can't empty that. Which means that there's water sitting in there...getting stagnant, growing bacteria and God knows what else. Yes, I'm a bit OCD when it comes to microbiology. But I don't like to drink water that's been sitting around for days, even if it's being "boiled".  I can only hope that bacteria are being destroyed, but who knows. I guess this machine would be fine if there were multiple coffee drinkers living in a house and the water was continually being circulated and replenished. But I wouldn't recommend it for circumstances like mine.
review_title: Not good if you only drink one cup of coffee a day
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: dgw
review_text: Everything about his model brewer from Keurig turns me off.  It feels cheap, very thin and light material.  Every time I go to remove a pod after brewing, the pod holder dislodges itself from the brewer.  Out of the first several cups we made, water came pouring out over the front of the machine.  Now I seem to be getting a lot of grounds in my coffee.  Should have spent a little more money and purchased the higher priced unit.  The model we had for four or five years that just died, they don't make it anymore - Go Figure.  Probably will always buy Keurig brewers, just purchased the wrong model.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Amazon Customer
review_text: I have been a Keurig user for 6 years. Sad to say my original Keurig stopped working. I know. I know all about the cleaning, paper clip etc. I did it. The machine was done. I did not want the 2.0 Keurig because of the proprietary cups it required. I like Crazy Cups I order from Amazon, and others. So I ordered the K-Select. Couldn t believe how light in weight it was. When I threw out the old one it was so much heavier. The K-Select is made of cheap plastic and it looks it too. No metal plate where the cup sits. Only plastic. So ugly. It also doesn t have the light in the water tank that looks chic on the counter. But it was reasonably priced. I should have splurged on the 2.0 I guess. But it makes a great tasting cup of coffee. Love the strong button. While it looks cheap, right now it does make great coffee. So I will use it until it breaks, which likely won t be 6 years like my last Keurig, based on the cheap plastic and light weight of the machine.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: JOY
review_text: I sent it back. For me, it was just too weak of a coffee. I tried many kinds of pods and the kind you fill up yourself. Even though I used the strong brew and tried all the serving sizes it was too weak for me. I wanted it to make fast iced coffee so this would not work. My mother has a different Keri s and I liked hers and gave this a try. It is fast and so convenient. If you prefer weak coffee, you may love this.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Charm
review_text: After getting a warehouse deal with a soggy box, I decided to take a chance and keep this brewer since it was such a good price. The brewer has worked very well. It heats quicker than my old one and I love the "extra caffeine" button. I also love having a size option for a travel mug. Brewer is sleeker than my old one and takes up less space. My old one still works but I use it at work while the nice red brewer brightens up my kitchen and takes up less of my limited counter space.
review_title: Bright, Sleek and Does the Job!
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Anton Ego
review_text: So far very happy (2 weeks in use). Bought it for office: no mess, no issues, quick and easy brew. Coffee taste is not like from french press freshly ground but very decent comparing with other drip coffee makers especially if you buy Peet's or Starbucks. You can brew your own ground coffee in the reusable mesh filter (sold separately). You can make tea as well, same taste as tea bags but the price will be much higher. I ended up not using "strong" option, and mostly use 8 oz size. I like 52 oz reservoir, no need to run for water every time you are making coffee ir tea.
review_title: So far very happy (2 weeks in use)
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Diane

I'm just pointing out the difference and that change can be good.

product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Gary LLL Williams
review_text: I love my Keurig! Even a small 4 cup pot was too much and was awful if left on the heat for several hours or simply wasted if tossed out (even reheating in the microwave was unsatisfactory)...let s face it, everyone LOVES fresh brewed coffee!  Now, every cup is fresh brewed!  Also note that pretty much every brand, flavor, and strength of coffee is avaliable in K-cups.  For those of us that like bold (strong) coffee, it has a  stronger  button...I like that.
review_title: Fresh brewed coffee and very time...love it!
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Debbie56
review_text: This is my third Keurig brewer and I like this one more than any other. This brewer will give hot water by just selecting the amount of ounces you need. I used to keep a self-fill K-cup in the brewer to get hot water. It is so nice to get hot water at the press of a button!
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Dennis Dillon
review_text: I don't know what it is about Keurig machines, but I seem to have bad luck with them. I purchased a deluxe unit with an LED touch screen, and it goes blank, so I got this one. I figures that this one only had buttons, nothing to go wrong, I was wrong. Periodically this one when you push the power button will just start running water through the cup spout. It just keeps going. I have to swap out coffee cups when the get filled with just unheated water. After doing this for a while the machine just shuts itself off. I have to unplug the unit for abot ten minutes,a nd then it might work again.
product_name: Keurig K-Select Single Serve K-Cup Pod Coffee Maker

name: Susan K. Walker
review_text: I was a big surprised at how light and flimsy Keurig makes these coffee makers.  The plastic is very cheap - hope it lasts.  Otherwise, it makes a great, quick, cup of coffee.  I have used Keurig for many years, all sizes, all quality.  You can't go wrong with these coffee makers.  I bought a single cup maker for my office at work and has lasted 3 jobs and about 7 years now.
review_title: Makes good coffee, cheaper plastic - not top quality but well worth the money.

I checked my spam folder, with the rep on the phone, and I told her exactly what email I got. She still wouldn't budge. She sent me an email for a coupon for 2 free boxes with free shipping, but obviously that's not the same thing. The coffee is good, definitely tastes a little different than when you brew in a regular coffee pot, not quite as rich & deep in flavor, if that makes sense. review_text: Recently decided to make the switch to K cups and settled on this "middle of the road" coffee maker.  Size was important to me as well as the 12 ounce size option. This K Select machine is a bit shorter than the K 200 series and has a slim resevoir on the side- a plus for anyone who does not want to pull out from under a counter to fill.  I'm finding the strong button a plus, too. This slows the process down a bit and for someone like me who fills their own coffee pods, it works well.  I can mix and match to taste, and seem to get a better flavor to the coffee, which is the whole point, right? On work days I use a Tervis tall mug, mid sized, and fix one right before I head out the door. It fits perfectly and I use the 12 oz setting. It leaves enough room for my lid, cream if I choose, and is ready in a flash.  The K Select has an auto off setting (2hrs) that you may disable. I have mine on as it takes little time to rev up (heat up) if it happens to turn off, and if I forget - well, it really does not matter. Overall I like it and will see if it holds up for a couple years- it is very plastic, and so time will tell. I have the black model, but would have preferred a sandy pearl -  none offered for this K Select, so  red or black,  either is a good choice for a no frills K cup maker.  Giving 4 stars since the color choices are so limited, but all else is pretty good with Amazon ordering and delivery superb as usual.

We may try to pay for a different model replacement if possible through the manufacturer so we don't end up returning the same model multiple times. I will update the review depending on our experience working with Keurig on a replacement and how that replacement will hold up. At present we cannot recommend purchasing this K-Select K80 due to this major flooding issue if left unattended. name: Spyce
review_text: My other Keurig is a Platinum Plus Series that I purchased several years ago. It has held up well over the years. The Keurig K-Select brewer is a midrange brewer that doesn't have fancy displays and settings. The coffee brews in under a minute, and it offers a Strong Brew setting, Auto Shutoff (two hours after last brew cycle), and a indicator light for when the machine needs to be descaled. The Strong Brew adds a little pizazz to this basic brewer. I like that feature a lot. The documentation doesn't explain the feature. I guess you get a stronger brew because the coffee takes a bit longer to brew. However, it works, it works very well. This machine has 4 brew sizes in ounces - 6, 8, 10, & 12 and like the other brewers, the cup holder can be removed for cups up to 7.4" tall. The reservoir holds 52 ounces and has a maximum fill line, but I stay a little bit under that because the water overflows when I place it back onto the base. The reservoir holds 8 ounces less than my other Keurig, it's just a cup, but I have to refill it frequently. The brewer features Quiet Brew Technology that is supposed to minimize noise during use. Well, my brewer is really loud so I don't think it works. Overall, the K-Select is a nice midrange brewer that is short on features, but brews a great cup of coffee.

name: Editor of Lillian's Diaries
review_text: We already have a Keurig 2.0 single serve that we have had for almost 3 years and are very pleased with it's performance. But as time goes on we know there will come a day when it will need to be replaced ( and having two single serves going during a party is a big help too). Therefore, I selected the Keurig K80 to review for VineVoice. The K80 is much sleeker than the 2.0 ( about 12 inches high and 9 inches in width) so it takes up less counter space. The Keurig K 80 offers a fourth cup size choice - 12 ounces which is a size not offered on the 2.0  (which offers  4-6-10 ounces). I personally will like the 12 ounce choice rather than making two separate cups. The K80 has simplified this single serve. You don't have the clock feature or the little written messages anymore but you have tiny lights in the top right corner to let you know that it is time to add water, time to descale and there is now an auto off light. There is a tiny button to increase the strength of the brew in the same area as the lights. The one feature I would change on my K2.0 is the drip tray that is not attached at all and thus slips and slides whenever you move the actual Keurig. The K80 has addressed that issue. There is a platform connected to the Keurig and the actual drip tray fits snugly onto that platform.

review_text: I have an old Keurig machine and needed a replacement one. The "strong" feature was very enticing to me.
